Brazil is already challenging the US on one of its main export crops, soybeans.
It's only beginning to export cotton, but US cotton producers are concerned.
David Cruz has two big cotton producers on his board, and Brazil Iowa Farms is looking to expand the 10,000 acres of cotton it currently has under cultivation.
Cruz is sensitive to criticism, though, that he's asking US farmers essentially to invest in their competition.
But he sees it another way; that by investing in Brazil, US farmers are capturing the profit there and bringing it back here.
We're going down and buying out the competition and controlling it in that manner.
And I believe that we're a very aggressive form of competition in world agriculture that way.
Back on his hog farm, Dick Gilmore sees his Brazil investment as just one more way to hedge against risk.
He says farmers routinely buy futures in crop insurance to protect themselves against weather and market fluctuations.
He says it's globalization now that represents uncertainty for farmers.
He argues that investing in Brazil is no different from what his ancestors did when immigrating to Iowa in the 1800s.
We have jet airplanes flying over the frontier now of where my great-grandfather homesteaded here, and we still farm some of that land.
Globalization, it's not really a new idea because my great-great-grandfather was thinking globalization when they moved to the United States.
That same pioneer spirit took Brian Willott to Brazil.
Willott is a former economist who grew up on a Missouri farm.
A few years ago, when he turned 30, he says he decided Brazil represented his chance to get back to farming.
He moved there, spent a year learning the language and last year planted his first crop of cotton and soybeans on 1,700 acres in western Bahia.
Reached on his cell phone in Bahia, Willott said that farming in Brazil is not for everyone.
On one hand, you leave everything that's familiar and all your family and friends and the people you love.
But at the same time, you get to meet new people and new experiences, to break new ground, to be the first one to farm something.
You have to enjoy that kind of experience to be willing to come down here.
While Willott says he hasn't made as much money as expected, he still enjoys farming in Brazil.
He says the most difficult challenge has been adapting to a new culture.
Americans who go to Brazil for farming also find they have to learn to cope with a new language, an unfamiliar financial system and a different pace of conducting business.
